raw_text:
Grammys honour soul star Charles
 
 The memory of soul legend Ray Charles dominated the music world's leading music ceremony on Sunday as he was given eight posthumous Grammy Awards.
 
 Charles, who died in 2004, got honours including record and album of the year, while Alicia Keys and actor Jamie Foxx performed a musical tribute to him. R&B star Keys won four awards herself at the Grammy ceremony in Los Angeles. U2, Usher, Norah Jones and Kanye West got three each. West led the race going into the ceremony with 10 nominations.
 
 Charles' last album, Genius Loves Company, a collection of duets that has sold more than two million copies, was named album of the year and best pop vocal album. His song Here We Go Again with Norah Jones won record of the year and best pop vocal collaboration, while Heaven Help Us All with Gladys Knight picked up best gospel performance. Jones said: "I'm glad he's getting recognised, because of who he is and how much I love him." Actor Jamie Foxx - who is nominated for an Oscar for playing Charles in the hit movie Ray - dedicated a rendition of Georgia on My Mind to "old friends". Keys, looking to replicate her Grammys success of 2002, when she won five, picked up best R&B song for You Don't Know My Name and best R&B album for The Diary of Alicia Keys. She also shared the award for best R&B vocal performance by a duo or group with Usher for My Boo.
 
 Usher's other victories were for best contemporary R&B album for Confessions and best rap/sung collaboration for Yeah!, featuring Lil Jon and Ludacris. Kanye West dominated the rap categories, winning best rap song for Jesus Walks and best rap album for The College Dropout. But in one of the night's biggest shocks, he lost out in the battle to be named best new artist to pop rock act Maroon 5. Vertigo by rock giants U2 won three trophies - best rock song, best short video and best rock vocal performance by a duo or group. One of the other main awards, song of the year, went to US singer-songwriter John Mayer for Daughters. Mayer also won best male pop vocal performance. Britney Spears picked up her first ever Grammy for her song Toxic, which was named best dance recording.
 
 Rod Stewart also won the first Grammy of his career, getting the best traditional pop album award for Stardust... The Great American Songbook: Volume III. In 2003, Stewart said he was "astounded" he had never won a Grammy - but "they tend not to give it to the British unless you're Sting". There were few other high-profile British victors this year. Annie Lennox, metal group Motorhead and dance act Basement Jaxx all took home trophies. But Elvis Costello, who had four nominations, and Joss Stone and Franz Ferdinand, who were both up for three awards, got nothing.
 
 Beach Boys veteran Brian Wilson was another first-time winner - for best rock instrumental performance. "It represents triumph and achievement in music that I feel that I deserved, and I'm really glad I won," he said. A live recording of composer John Adams' 11 September tribute, On the Transmigration of Souls, performed by the New York Philharmonic, won three classical prizes. And former US President Bill Clinton picked up the second Grammy of his career, winning the spoken word award for the audio version of his autobiography My Life.
llama3.2:1b: Ray Charles received eight posthumous Grammy Awards, including record and album of the year, as well as awards in R&B, gospel, pop vocal collaboration, and more. Other winners included U2, Kanye West, Norah Jones, Alicia Keys, and John Mayer.
llama3.2:3b: Grammy Awards honored soul legend Ray Charles posthumously with eight awards including record and album of the year, as well as performances by Alicia Keys and Jamie Foxx. R&B star Alicia Keys won four awards, while Usher, Norah Jones, and Kanye West each won three. Charles' last album was named album of the year and his song "Here We Go Again" with Norah Jones won record of the year. Other winners included Britney Spears for best dance recording, Rod Stewart for best traditional pop album, and Beach Boys veteran Brian Wilson for best rock instrumental performance.
gemma2:2b: Ray Charles received eight posthumous Grammy Awards including album and record of the year. Alicia Keys and Jamie Foxx performed tributes to him. U2, Usher, Norah Jones, and Kanye West all won multiple awards.  John Mayer won song of the year. Other notable winners include Rod Stewart, Brian Wilson, Annie Lennox, Motorhead, Basement Jaxx, John Adams' orchestral work for 11 September, Bill Clinton.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The memory of soul legend Charles died in 2004 and was honoured with eight posthumous Grammy Awards in Los Angeles, including a record and album of the year, while actors Jamie Foxx, Alicia Keys, Usher, Norah Jones, and Kanye West all received awards for their performances.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Ray Charles received eight posthumous Grammy Awards at the ceremony honoring him as a soul legend, including record and album of the year, best pop vocal album, and various song and collaboration wins. Keys also won four awards herself, while Kanye West dominated rap categories with three nominations, losing to Maroon 5 for best new artist.
qwen2.5:3b: The Grammys honored soul legend Ray Charles posthumously with eight awards including record and album of the year honors. Alicia Keys won four trophies, while Usher and Kanye West took home three each. Key highlights include Ray Charles' duet album "Genius Loves Company" being named album of the year; his collaboration with Norah Jones winning record of the year; and Jamie Foxx's performance including a tribute to Charles in the musical genre tribute segment. Kanye West dominated rap categories, but lost best new artist to Maroon 5. Rod Stewart won his first Grammy for "Stardust... The Great American Songbook: Volume III." Classical category winners included On the Transmigration of Souls by John Adams and spoken word winner Bill Clinton's autobiography "My Life."
opencoder:1.5b: "Soul legend Charles's memory of eight posthumous Grammys at a music ceremony marked a remarkable milestone in his life. He won multiple awards, including a record and album of the year and five other top nominations. Through his song 'Here We Go Again,' he emerged as one of the most distinguished figures in R&B and pop music. His contribution to the industry revolution was evident in the performance of 'You Don't Know My Name.' A tribute to a friend named Norah Jones who shared the success of his work with her." - Charles' biography.
smollm:1.7b:
The Grammys are a prestigious music awards ceremony that recognizes excellence in various genres of music. The winners receive eight trophies and are given an opportunity to perform their songs live at the ceremony. The winners are chosen by a panel of judges who evaluate the performances based on criteria such as technical skill, creativity, and overall impact.

The Grammys have been dominated by American artists in recent years, with many winners coming from the US. However, there were some notable winners from other countries, including the UK, Canada, and Australia. The ceremony has also become more diverse, with a greater representation of women and people of color among the winners.

The 2019 Grammy Awards saw several notable winners, including American singer-songwriter Taylor Swift, who won for her album "Reputation". Other notable winners included Australian singer-songwriter Kylie Minogue, who won for her album "Dancing with You", and Canadian singer-songwriter Justin Bieber, who won for his album "Love Yourself".

The 2019 Grammy Awards also saw several nominations and wins from various genres of music. For example, the Best Contemporary R&B/Hip-Hop Performance category was won by American singer-songwriter Ariana Grande, while the Best Traditional Pop Instrumental Solo Performance category was won by British singer-songwriter Ed Sheeran.

Overall, the 2019 Grammy Awards were a celebration of excellence in music from around the world, with many winners coming from diverse backgrounds and genres.

Charles RayCharles (2004-2016) received multiple Grammy Awards for his contributions to various music categories. He was honored with eight awards, including record and album of the year, best performance tributes, R&B, pop, rap, and rock categories. His work as a singer songwriter and artist earned recognition in multiple categories, while others like Alicia Keys, U2, Usher, and Kanye West also secured notable wins.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Grammys celebrated soul legend Ray Charles by honoring him with eight posthumous awards. Ray Charles received record and album of the year for "Genius Love," a collection of songs that sold over two million copies, while Alicia Keyes and actor Jamie Foxx performed a musical tribute to him at the ceremony in Los Angeles. R&B stars Norah Jones and Kanye West won three awards each, including best new artist and song of the year for "Dawn," which won over Maroon 5's best rock song ("Daughters"). In one of the biggest shocks, U2's John Mayer won best rock vocal performance, beating out Britney Spears in the category. The other main awards went to Rod Stewart and "Starstruck...The Great American Songbook: Volume III" by Annie Lennox, Motorhead, Basement Jaxx, Elvis Costello and Jossi Stone, while music legend Brian Wilson won best rock instrumental performance for a live recording of composer John Adams' 11 September tribute. Bill Clinton picked up the spoken word award for his autobiography My Life.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The Grammy Awards are awarded annually in various music categories to honor outstanding achievements and contributions to the industry. This year, Ray Charles was posthumously honored with eight Grammys, including record and album of the year for his critically acclaimed 2004 album, Genius Loves Company. The other notable recipients included U2, Usher, Alicia Keys, Kanye West, John Mayer, Rod Stewart, and Elvis Costello.

Alicia Keys won four awards, including best R&B vocal performance by a duo or group, while U2, Usher, Norah Jones, and Kanye West each received three nominations. Kanye West led the competition with 10 nominations.
